questions.question: I haven’t invited ……………………….. them.
questions.description: We use either of before a pronoun.

questions.question: If either of the girls phones, tell ……………………… that I am busy.
questions.description: A pronoun used to refer back to either + noun / pronoun can be singular or plural.

questions.question: I hit the target ……………………… in the middle.
questions.description: When right is used before a preposition referring to place or movement, it means completely or exactly.

questions.question: We had ……………………… a thunderstorm last night.
questions.description: We can use quite with singular countable nouns to express the idea that something is remarkable. Rather is not possible with this meaning.

questions.question: She hasn’t got ……………………… for the job.
questions.description: As an adjective enough goes before the noun modified by it.

questions.question: Although my grandfather is eighty-five, he enjoys ………………………….
questions.description: Health is an uncountable noun we cannot use the article ‘a’ with it.

questions.question: The house …………………….. I live in is very spacious.
questions.description: That…in means the same as where.

questions.question: Because I was ill for six months, …………………….. lost my job.
questions.description: Use so or because in a sentence. Don’t use them both.

questions.question: Rahul lives in ………………….
questions.description: We do not normally use the with singular proper names.

questions.question: ……………………. child can learn to swim.
questions.description: Any and every can both be used to talk in general about all the members of a class or group.

questions.question: ………………………. I didn’t understand a word, I kept smiling.
questions.description: Even if refers to the present or future. Even though refers to the past.
